<center>{{quote|Yea, 'tis an unhappy tale, for sorrow hath fared ever abroad among [[Men]] and doth so still, but in the wild days were very terrible things done and suffered; and yet hath [[Melko]] seldom devised more cruelty, nor do I know a tale that is more pitiful.|Eltas in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales Part Two]]'', "[[Turambar and the Foalókë]]"}}</center>

'''Eltas''' was a [[man]] whose people lived in a vale of [[Hisilómë]] and that he had come to [[Tol Eressëa]] by [[Olórë Mallë]] "in the days before the fall of [[Gondolin]]". The ''[[Turambar and the Foalókë|Tale of Turambar]]'' he had heard from the older men of his people who hated [[Melko]] and his "evil worms".<ref name=Turambar>{{LT2|II}}</ref>{{rp|70, 118}}

He was in the [[Cottage of Lost Play]] on the second day of the feast of [[Turuhalmë]]; in the absence of [[Gilfanon|Ailios]], Eltas told the tale of ''[[Turambar and the Foalókë]]'' to [[Eriol]].<ref name=Turambar />{{rp|69–70}}

After the ''Tale of Turambar'' Eltas was asked to tell the story of [[the Nauglafring]], but he said that the tales of [[Tuor]] and [[Beren]] should be told first.<ref name=Turambar />{{rp|144}} However, he didn't tell the story of the Nauglafring, and he doesn't appear any more.
